description:
In Rise!, players race to be the first to construct three towers on the growing game board, moving workers to and fro to keep the towers rising and the opponent befuddled.

To set up, place 12 hexagonal tiles in a dogbone shape as specified in the rulebook, then place one token for each player on their starting locations. On a turn, a player takes two actions (possibly the same action twice) from this list of options:


    Place a land tile adjacent to any existing tile.
    Place a worker adjacent to any of your workers already on the game board.
    Move one of your workers to an adjacent empty space.
    Jump an opponent's worker and land on an empty space, removing that worker from play.
    Remove two of your workers from the board to remove an opponent's worker from any space.
    Remove two of your workers from the board to place one of your workers in any empty space.
    Remove one of your tower layers from the board.


If at any time during play you have a circle of six of your workers surrounding an empty space, place the first layer of one of your towers in that space. Your ring of workers must remain in place for two additional turns for the remaining two layers to be added to the tower; if your ring is disrupted, you can complete it later to continue the tower-building. If you completely surround an opponent's tower, you can remove the top level of that tower from the board.

In addition to building three complete towers, a player can also win by eliminating all of the opponent's workers from the game board.

Objective: be the first to visit 5 capital cities within Europe
- moving by turn -
1st choose side of the map (geographical or political)
2nd draw card to find starting position
3rd draw additional 5 cards and 'form' a route
4th roll the die and move your meeple
5th you may use cards (max 2 =) ship and plane tickets instead of your die
5th if the roll shows a symbol draw an action card and proceed
as described

Crayon-rails style game in Italy, including the islands of Sicily and Sardinia. This is a pick-up-and-deliver affair in which players draw railroad tracks on the map on which they run their trains to satisfy demand cards. Connecting all of the country's major cities is required. Upgrading train abilities is possible. Achieve victory by being first to achieve a set amount of cash on hand.

Innovations: 
â—‹ staggered ferry pricing
â—‹ public-locking rules standard
â—‹ demand cards sorted by value

Objective: make most of your money manipulating the running-in
- moving by turns -
1 each player draws a hidden card which proposes a different running-in of the 5 (coloured) horses
2 each player rolls 3 coloured dice - colours on top designate the horses to be moved during this turn - 3, 2 and 1 space
by choice of the active player
3 if a die shows a horseshoe - free choice
4 obstacles and/or special positions are going to change/modify results
5 if all horses have crossed the finish line there is a check/comparison how many positions are matching with the running-in proposal on your card
6 after collecting points players will run 2 additional rounds

From the publisher:

"Power-Up the World’s most popular matching game – MEMORY!

Challenge yourself to the classic game of Memory with a Super Mario™ twist. Turn over cards and find their match. Pick up an Item Card to add more fun and challenge. The player with the most matches wins!

Game includes: 52 Character Cards, 20 Item Cards and Rules."

Item cards distinguish this version of Memory from the original by giving players special powers, as items do in the Mario series of video games.  For example, by picking up the matched Yoshi's Egg cards, a player can take the matched Yoshi cards away from another player. The Super Star cards protect a player from other item card actions.

Turn learning into a game and kids will want to play. Based on What Do You Stand For? For Kids by Barbara A. Lewis.

To win, players collect cards of each trait. Each card features a "What If" scenario or question about character that gets kids thinking about what they would do-and what they stand for. Meant to be played with adult supervision (a teacher, counselor, or youth worker familiar with character education themes), the game includes an insert with rules and basic character education concepts.

Hidden Rules (or Hidden Curriculum) is a term used to describe the unwritten social rules and behaviors that most of us seem to know without ever being taught, such as respecting those in a position of authority, acknowledging others' personal space, speaking at an appropriate volume, paying attention to body language, and more. This fun card game will help children learn and practice 40 hidden rules for everyday life. The object of play is to be the first player to get rid of all their cards.

Contents:
10 blue Hidden Rules Cards
10 red Hidden Rules Cards
10 green Hidden Rules Cards
10 yellow Hidden Rules Cards
10 blue number cards
10 red number cards
10 green number cards
10 yellow number cards
5 Wild cards
5 Skip-a-Turn Wild Cards
8 blank cards (2 of each color)
Instructions

From the publisher:

The Battle of Mollwitz, April 10, 1741, was the first field battle between the Austrians and the Prussians in what the Prussians called the First Silesian War. While the Austrian Empire was in the throes of a succession crisis and was threatened by other countries, "Frederick the Great" (Friedrich II of Prussia) seized the Austrian province of Silesia. When the Austrians did react, they placed an army between Frederick and Prussia. Frederick turned and approached the Austrians in a snow storm. He had to defeat the Austrian army to re-establish his lines of communication.

Comment:

Battle of Mollwitz is a free beginner-level desktop-published (DTP) game by Chris Salander published by online boardgaming magazine The Boardgaming Life. The game comes in a PDF file comprising rules, map and 24 counters.

Electronic quiz game. When you answer a question, you touch the connection and a light will come on if you are right.

275 questions sounds like it won't have much replayability.

Fringe The Apocalypse is an unique science, standards based board game, three years in the making that helps kids gain a critical thinking advantage in the sciences. The game academics with game playing fun. 2 - 8 players must balance strategic goals with game playing challenges in an attempt to successfully navigate two worlds, fighting and collaborating with aliens while acquiring necessary gear, keys and dropa stones. Become strong enough to defeat Boss Zygos and enter the wormhole to save earth from an impending apocalypse.

Choose between the Family or School Editions. Each edition focuses on learning in an all new, fun and exciting way. You must be smart, aggressive and cooperative as your aliens race, battle, negotiate and outsmart your opponents. Enter Maze and Portal Challenges and gain advantage over your opponents. Beware! you must acquire and use the Arc of light to save earth before the end of days apocalypse where all players lose - game over!

Dark Matter, Black Holes, White Holes, Wormholes, The Fourth Dimension, anti-gravity and various barriers await you. Time machines, Teleport Tunnels, Maze of the Ancients, Tower of Power and Portal challenges can be used to your advantage. Answer Mystery and grade level Science questions at each stage of the game. Play your Alien Power cards and Gear cards wisely to win the game.

Mein Tag (My day) is from Haba My Very First Games Series. It contains 2 games with the day- starting theme.


     Waking up and starting the day!


A first funny color placement memory game for two little sleepyheads. The players have to search for a tile that matches the color of the last one to have been placed.


     Ready, steady, let the new day begin!


On the die appears: One, two or three dots? Take your figure and move it forward on to the end of the tiles. The die shows the tired face, go over to the next player. The player who reaches the red tile first wins the game.

British card game. No publisher mentioned anywhere but I do know it was made by a company called James Cond Ltd.

Scoop is a frantic game in the manner of the better known Pit. Players don't have turns, instead they just call out for the card they want. They can only call the name of the card they want to get rid off, not the colour. The first player to get all seven 'Scoops' in one colour, wins.

There are penalty cards and a player cannot win if he has penalty cards in his hand so it is important to get rid of them quickly.

Each player positions his marker on the start spot and takes one mouse-, duck- and elephant tile each in the same colour. In his move a player takes the top card and reads out the question, mouse, duck and elephant offer one answer each, which is also read out. Then all players decide on the correct answer and place the corresponding animal tile face down. When all have decided, the tiles are turned up, for a correct answer a player moves his marker one spot forward, the active player two spots. The first player to reach the finish, wins the game.

Using motives from the TV show "Die Maus" this collection of learning games offers three different games for children from age 3.

Lerne Zählen teaches them the numbers from 1-12 and helps to find them in day-to-day situations.

Mein Zuhause concentrates on daily things and situations in the nursery and all over the house.

Lerne die Uhr teaches them a feeling for time and shows in play how the clock can help to manage the day better.

Fox and crow wander the world, escaping dangerous situations and dicovering amazing treasures. And eating pancakes. They always have time for pancakes.

Yay Pancakes is a Print and Play bluffing game.

Players take turns laying down cards that tell part of Fox and Crow's story in a somewhat logical order. If a someone plays a "Yay Pancakes" card, they collect all the cards on the table.

When no-one else can play, whoever has the most points wins.

Four beautiful game on "Seasons", where children get to know the year it expires. The game  helps them with the lovingly crafted images, they also find in their own environment . Four funny put, place and dice games running around the year in one box.

1. Schau, wie lang ist ein Jahr! (Look, how long is a year!)
- Color-match game, where the players have to put the 12 month together. The first who has all 12 month in the correct order wins the game
2. Gemeinsam durch das Jahr! (Together through the year!)
- the same as game 1, but as an coperative game with a figure and a dice to go through the month tiles.
3. Kunterbunt durch das Jahr!  (Motley through the year!)
- a game while all the month-tiles mixed in a circle. the boy and the girl starts on a choosen tile and by rolling the color die the player try to reach the next color-matching tile. Who is first back at the starting point wins the game.
4. Von Januar bis Juni und weiter! (From January to June, and more!)
- One player starts on the January tile the other on the June. They try to find the next month after there starting tile, (small memory game). The player who first reaches the tile of the other player wins the game.

There Must Be No Competition, Before World Domination

In Hench: The Game, you take on the role of an evil mad scientist that has the means to rule the world, but so do a few others just like you! Before you can take over the world, you need to eliminate the competition.

Hench: The Game will be a simple card and dice game (recommended for 2-4 players). From your hand of 6 cards, you build your army of henchmen to protect you using Recruit Cards, and who will also do all your dirty work for you. You can strengthen your henchmen army by building enhancements to your secret hideout or equipping them with weapons. You can also attack, sabotage, defend yourself and many other things using Event Cards from your hand.

Basic gameplay will go like this:

1.As your turn begins, you may play a Recruit Card to play henchmen from your hand (but keeping some hidden in your hand may be beneficial to you later)
2.You then can play one Enhancement, Weapon or Event card from your hand (see FAQ for card type explanation)
3.If an Event card is played, instead of a Weapon or Enhancement card, then all effects from the card are resolved
4.Draw back up to 6 cards.
5.Next player's turn

If an Event card, such as Direct Attack or Provoked Attack, are played, then combat starts. How combat works is your opponent and yourself add up your "Hench Power", which is +1 for each henchman you have in play, and any modifiers from Weapon or Enhancements in play. Each battling player then rolls one D6 and adds it to their "Hench Power". Higher number wins, and the loser can either lose a location enhancement or half the difference between the "Hench Power" numbers (round up) in henchmen they have in play.

Some other Event cards would allow you to avoid a battle (but you end up losing a turn), forcing a battle between two other players, performing suicide attacks, etc.You lose when all of your henchmen are destroyed, and the last player standing wins the game, and the world!

Four simple games teach how to remember stories and facts and how to retell them properly. This trains fantasy and verbal development. 
"Unterwegs mit der Maus" is a combination game, cards must be put on the boards, the situations have a time sequence. 
"Schnell geschaut" is a reaction game, a game master combines 3 fitting and one non-fitting card, players score a point for finding the misfit. 
"Was könnte das sein" is a description game, players must name the words describes. 
"Quatschgeschichten" is a repetition game, the first player tells a story containing the three words on his card, the next players repeat the story and add their own things, a mistake scores a minus.

The jetty is rather narrow and the bear and his friends jostle each other while trying to catch a fish. The player in position 1 is the one to begin to fish, he rolls the die and if the die shows a 1 or 2 he has caught the corresponding number of fish. He may go on rolling the die. If a blue 1 appears he falls into the pond and has to line up again in last place. All others move forward one spot and the number 1 now starts fishing. If the die shows a red 2, the player in position 2 falls into the pond and has to line up in the back. Who is the first to catch 12 or 18 fish, depending on the number of players, wins the game.

There are many things to find from Panamaland to the little hut beside the river, and players must be lucky three times to move and win the game. Players start with their tiger at the hut, the bear stands on any Panama card. The active player rolls the die. Now he needs to find two more cards identical to the one the bear stands on. If he is lucky, the are already there face up, otherwise the player may turn over up to three cards to find the necessary motives. If he has found them, he may move his tiger as many spots as he has rolled, otherwise the tiger stays in place. The player to be the first to get back to the hut beside the river wins the game.

Creative Kitchen is board game that brings together your creative and culinary skills while mixing in a few good laughs. Originally designed to help engage students at a local culinary training program in Savannah, Georgia (Starfish Café), the game has earned rave reviews from both home cooks and professional chefs in prototyping sessions.

The game is played by dealing each “chef contestant” a set of ingredient cards. Based off the mystery box ingredient concept popular in shows such as Food Network’s Chopped and Iron Chef, players can discard and pick up new ingredients in their quest to make the best recipe out of their hand. Contestants then have to name and illustrate their dish on provided recipe cards and sell it to their panel of judges (their fellow contestants!). Creative Kitchen is a great way to gather recipes from friends and share a few laughs over “interesting” recipes. Cheers to Creative Kitchen’s next master chef!

Currently, the board game design includes 110 ingredient cards (expansion decks to come!), game board, kitchen timing device, pad of blank recipe cards and eye catching Creative Kitchen box.

Haven Town is facing total annihilation at the hands (and teeth) of a horde of monsters from beyond the Shadowrift.

You, the heroes, must band together to drive them back. To do this, you will need powerful spells, skills, attacks and loot. When the game begins, you are a basic hero; you can explore and fight. Luckily for you, Shadowrift is a deck-building game! You can buy new cards to add to your deck, cards that will define you as an adventurer and complement the strengths of your fellow heroes. Unlike other deck-builders, there is constant interaction with your fellow players as you figure out who will gain which benefit from the limited supply of townsfolk, offer their coin to help construct walls, and seek healing from anyone who's learned such magic.

Shadowrift also features monsters that don't merely sit waiting to be slain; if you leave them alone, they will rip Haven Town asunder. They'll kill people, break walls, and kick your heroes in the face. Combat with them is intuitive (though frequently painful). For defeating a monster, heroes gain Heroism, a simple, consistent boost to their power that makes them better at anything they undertake. Since the monsters won't stop coming until the last Shadowrift is sealed or the town has been built into a mighty fortress, you'll need every boost you can take.

The second edition of Shadowrift features many improved mechanisms, including a revised system for how monsters choose who to attack (based on types of villagers, instead of specific people) and a new system for monster powers (making them much more dangerous). It also has a revised card layout and a great deal of new and improved artwork.

GAME ON is the very first live card game.
The Game is played while watching a sports event.

There is a special deck made for each sport:

     Baseball
     Football
     Hockey
     Basketball
     Soccer
     Golf
     Tennis


The two most popular ways of playing GAME ON….

Each player (2-5 players) are dealt 7 random cards. Leave the leftover cards in a pile, they will be used soon.  Now.....

1. Let the sports event decide what cards to play by what is actually happening in the game. The goal is to dump all of your cards first. If the next play is running back running for 15+ yards and you have that card then you can play it. That is once less card you have to dump AND if that card you use is a + or - card then you get to dump more of your cards or have a player (or two) pick more cards up from the leftover pile. Its that simple.....AND FUN!!

2. Play your cards by predicting what will happen next in the game. The goal is to collect as many cards as possible. Before the next chance (inning, possession, break, etc...) each player chooses a play from the hand they are dealt. Place it face up so everyone knows whos playing what. When the first person who chose correctly wins then he/she gets to collect all the cards that were played. Plus if his/her card was a +/- card then she could get more cards from the leftover pile or they can choose the cards that other players have to dump. Trade cards are used as well and when you win with that card you get to pick a players card (blindly) to trade with your worst card. Its that simple....AND FUN!

***There are many other ways of playing GAME ON. Other luck games or harder games involving more skills and knowledge.***

Each sport has between 8-13 different plays in the deck. Some are rare but most are common plays.

Centipedes want to be as long as possible to stand out from their fellow 'pedes and in SchuhBidu players can help them grow and grow – but only if they have shoes to place on the centipede feet.

At the start of the game, each player takes a centipede "head" tile, while the feet tiles are placed in the center of the table. On a turn, the active player rolls all four dice, sets aside any he wishes, then rerolls up to two more times, with the option of rerolling dice set aside after the first throw. After his third roll (or earlier, if he wishes), he can take any one foot tile for which he has matching symbols on the dice (with suns counting as a wild symbol) and add it to his centipede

The game ends after all the feet tiles have been claimed, and the player with the longest centipede wins. The rules include a variant for older players in which you can steal shoes from an opponent.

The heart of the game are 55 double-sided cards, thus presenting 110 important phrases, words or questions, specially geared to holiday needs and packed separately in a plastic box for easy transport. A ring-track on the board shows empty spots and spots with city names. Players roll the die and move their token, if it lands on a city name the player can try to translate one card. If the translation is correct he/she receives one chip. The first player to collect 5 chips wins the game.

A quiz in the form of a fan, on the subject of general knowledge - 'primary school level' -, 1000 questions and answers sequenced by time periods. The cards are held by a screw and can be ideally taken on travels, the answers are always on the next page. The quiz can be played alone or by several players.

Guerilla ! is a miniature skirmish ruleset published in Vae Victis magazine issue #15. The game simulates battles of the mid-nineteenth century, especially the many colonial wars of the era.

The game uses a simple chit-pull system to alternate figure activation. An activated figure can move and/or fire, reload a weapon or attack in close combat. The rules include the different firearms available at the time (muzzle- and breach-loading rifles, pistols and carbines), cavalry, cover, morale, experience levels (a veteran figure will reload a weapon faster and have bonuses to morale, shooting and close combat), and a scenario simulating the last moments of the battle of Camerone.

Scale: 1 mini = 1 man, 1 cm = 1 m, a turn = a few seconds

A familly game about a french movie (a big success).
An evil wizard has sent you in the twentieth century. To return to your epoque (1123 AD), you must find magical ingredients to reopen the corridors of time.
A fun game for a familly, an hard addiction for the movie's fans.
The goal : On a journey full of obstacles, traps, psychiatric hospitals, you must be the first to recover the three magic ingredients to return to your day. The first player to complete this conditions wins.
The manner : After a dice roll, you move your pawn on a case and you have a question about the film or you must make an imitation of the movie's actors (there are many ...) If you are correct, you can reroll another dice to get closer from a Magical Ingredient. The cases of the board need specific action, you lose your turn or change direction.
Components : 1 bonus roundel
             6 pawns
             1 8-sided die
             138 cards, Movie, Surprises, Imitations and Magic Potion.

The winner must say "Per Horus, et per Ra, et per Solem, in victus, luceres" and normally he must go back in 1123 AD...

An Offal Game for 1 or 2 players

Pity the poor people of Cadaver City. Long ago they filled up all their cemeteries with their loved (and not so loved) ones. Now they’ve run out of room so they have taken to dumping the bodies down the sewer (out of sight out of mind). You, enterprising 3rd Class Sewer Engineers (Plungers), see a chance to make some fast money and solve the corpse clog threatening to overwhelm the existing system. At a quiet back door behind the Treatment Plant a line of customers queue up for the bits and pieces you have on offer. Deliver them the right parts, aged to the right amount of time and you’ll receive your reward.

Needed to play: The deck of 27 cards
10 eurocubes in each of 4 colors for the body parts (white for Bones, brown for Organs, gray for Brains and red for Hearts) and 9 black eurocubes for the rats
1 eurocube marker in each of 2 other colors to keep track of player scores on the Gore Track
1 large bag [or an old sock] (the Bag O’ Parts) to hold all the body parts, 10 small ziplock bags to act as body bags in the game and 1 four-sided die

Setup: Place the 4 Sewer Pipe cards,  Gore Track, and the score markers between the Plungers (players).
Shuffle the customer deck and deal 2 customers to each Plunger, placing the rest in a face down draw pile known as “The Queue”, next to the Sewer Pipe. Each plunger should place their customers face up in front of them.
Shuffle the tool deck and deal 3 tools to each Plunger that they will use as their initial hand of cards. The remaining tool cards will be placed in a tool card draw deck next to The Queue.
Place the body bags within reach of both Plungers. Each Plunger should take 1 body bag for each customer they have during the game. Lastly place all the body parts and rats in the Bag O’ Parts.

Phase 1: Adding new body parts
Roll 1d4 and add that value to the number of waiting customers in front of them. The Plunger will then blind draw that number of body parts from the Bag O’ Parts. Shift all existing body parts towards The Clog to make room for the incoming body parts. Rats will never move. Set aside any body parts that are shifted off of the Day 3 card into a reserve pile. Place the new body parts in the order they are drawn on the Sewer Pipe cards beginning from the rightmost space on the Day 1 card. If any rats are drawn they will be placed on the Rat spaces beginning from the far left of the Day 3 card. Any body part occupying a Rat space where a Rat will be placed, during this phase, will be removed and tossed back into the Bag O’ Parts.

Roll 1d4 and place that many reserved Day 3 parts on The Clog card spaces, tossing the rest back in the Bag O’ Parts.

Phase 2: Filling orders
Each customer card lists the number of parts required to fill the order.

To fill an order a Plunger must choose all of any of 1 type of body parts on any one Sewer card (meeting the desired aging requirement) placing those parts in the customer’s body bag. Any extra body parts not needed for the orders go back in the Bag O’ Parts. Plungers may use the body parts to attempt to fill 1, 2 or more customer orders as long as the body parts are of the desired type and aging. If a customer’s complete order is filled the Plunger scores the money value, indicated in the lower right corner of the customer card, on the Gore Track. All body parts from this order are then tossed back in the Bag O’ Parts. A new customer is then drawn from The Queue.

Tool Cards: Each Plunger may use one of their tool cards at any point during their turn. Once played, the card will be placed on a discard pile next to the tool card draw pile and a new card is drawn.

Game End: The game ends in one of two ways:
a. The Clog card has become full of body parts. In this case, the current Plunger finishes their turn and any final scoring is marked.
b. All 10 customers have had their orders filled.

The Plunger who has earned the most money is declared the winner and receives a promotion to 2nd Class Sewer Engineer.

This game can be played solo as well. See the rules for modifications to the game.

This appears to be the first hockey game made by Gotham.
Game says that   patent applied   for  GOTHAM'S  G-200  TOY,  ICE HOCKEY GAME 
Manufactured by GOTHAM PRESSED STEEL CORP from NY USA. 
MADE IN UNITED STATES OF AMERICA. 
Game measures 24" long x 11" wide.

This is the same game as GOTHAM G-800 Ice Hockey game already in the DB. This game of course is different because it is not electric. You have to hand hold the goalies who resemble the look of the Electric G-800 goalies.

This game from McLoughlin Brothers was a game that featured a mechanical man who was controlled by the player. The scorecard that came with the game showed how long each hole was and a conversion into inches was then made by the players. There was an out-of bounds marker and a sand trap and movable green to navigate to and then with a deft touch the ball could be putted into the hole.

Iron & Steam is a rules system for playing out ironclad naval combat in the era of the American Civil War. Game play is relatively streamlined, while rules include a good amount of specific technical information to satisfy those wanting a greater degree of granularity and detail.  As such, the rules contain pre-generated game statistics for historical vessels, but also provide guidelines for converting any vessel to in-game play statistics.  Similarly, for simplicity identical gun ranges are suggested for any gun of a given type (e.g. smoothbore cannon), while for those players wishing to add more detail and realism an appendix is included with expanded gun statistics to differentiate historical guns of various manufacture.

The rules are designed to use a scale of 1:2400

Also included is a bibliography of suggested reading.

Harlequin cannot sit still, he jumps up and down, all limbs in different directions. Children try to immitate him with their harlequins. Each player receives a harlequin card and starts with arms and legs of the harlequin in a randomly chosen position. The cards are shuffled and seperated into three piles with 12 cards each. One player after the other moves an arm or leg of his harlequin exactly on step away from the previous position. If the new positions corresponds with the position of the harlequin on one of the three top cards in the stack, the player takes this card. When all cards are gone, the player with the most cards wins.

It's been three years since the nation's unification. Rumours have begun to spread of a rare and precious gem, discovered in the Mererani Hills of Northern Tanzania.

In Tanzania, players seek to increase their fortune, skill and renown to attain the most valuable gemstones. However, collecting gemstones is no easy task! Players will need to use their limited resource and clever planning to surpass the competition.

The game ends once two of the four markets (columns) have closed, after which the player with the most points is declared the winner.

Objective: be the first to pass finish line (field 75)
simple 'Roll and Move' game
remarks:
very cute drawings
humanized animals
2 educational inserts about bugs & butterflies by manufacturer
6 very nice coloured pewter figures
should had been published between 1910-15

Sugar Gliders is a board game for two to four players. Each game lasts around 20 minutes. Each player has a sugar glider, that has to collect as many fruits as possible by jumping from branch to branch.

The sugar glider is a small marsupial that loves nectarous foods. As its name suggests, it’s capable of gliding through the air, much like a flying squirrel.

COMPONENTS

- A board depicting a tree with 61 cells.
- 4 sugar gliders in different colours.
- 60 food tiles in 5 types: 1 fruit, 2 fruits, 3 fruits, 4 fruits, 1 big fruit (5 points).
- A carrying case.

GAME PREPARATION

Each player chooses a player color and takes the corresponding sugar glider.

Leaving the center space empty, randomly distribute the 60 tiles face-up to the 60 other spaces on the tree, 1 per space.

White starts by choosing any space with a white fruit (value 1 tile), and placing his sugar glider on it. The tile in that space will be his ‘jumping tile’. In turn, the other players do the same.
    
The game can start now. White plays first.

GAME RULES

The game is played in turns, counterclockwise. On your turn, you must either make your sugar glider jump or go into a brief state of torpor:

JUMP

Move your sugar glider in a straight line a number of spaces equal to your ‘jumping tile’ (this means one space in the first turn). If you have no ‘jumping tile’ underneath your sugar glider, you must use one from your reserve. Notice that purple fruits count as 5 movement points.

Then you take the ‘jumping tile’ that you just used, and put it beside yourself face-up. This is your ‘reserve’. If you had no ‘jumping tile’ underneath your sugar glider and had to use a tile from your reserve, discard this tile to the game case; it cannot be used again for the rest of the game.

The tile on which your sugar glider has landed (if any) is your new ‘jumping tile’.

Exceptions:

- The sugar gliders cannot jump outside the tree.
- A sugar glider sitting in the center space can jump to any space on the board by spending any tile from his reserve (no need to match the length of the jump).
- A sugar glider cannot move through another sugar glider.

Example: Anna wishes to make her sugar glider jump, but there is no ‘jumping tile’ underneath her sugar glider. She uses a ‘2’ from her reserve, moves the sugar glider 2 spaces in a straight line, and discards the tile she’s used to the case.

TORPOR

You don’t move your sugar glider. Take the ‘jumping tile’ from underneath your sugar glider (if there is one), and add it to your reserve.

GAME END

The game ends when all the sugar gliders are consecutively in a state of torpor, or when the tree runs out of tiles, whichever happens first.

Each player sums the values of the tiles in his reserve (purple tiles count as 5 points). Highest score wins. In case of a tie, play again.

VARIANT FOR 2 PLAYERS

For shorter 2-player games, discard all the purple fruit tiles and 3 tiles of each other value. Then play on the inner board.

Welcome to the future

The year is 2033. The world is in ruins. All the major cities have been wiped away by a nuclear war. Flooded with radiation, the planet surface is largely unfit for life. Handfuls of survivors have found refuge in antinuclear bunkers, the largest of which is the Moscow Metro. The Metro has become humanity’s last haven after Judgment Day.

Metro 2033 is based on the popular Metro 2033 universe created by Russian writer and journalist Dmitry Glukhovsky. After the nuclear strike, thousands of survivors have found refuge in the Moscow underground (a.k.a., the Metro) — the biggest shelter in the world. In the stations and tunnels deep below the surface a new civilization emerges.

Gameplay

Each player is a leader of one of the many factions of post-nuclear underground. In order to win, a faction has to achieve ten victory points (VPs). Each station under the faction's control gives it 1 VP; different quests also bring VPs when completed. The other way to win is to capture all four stations of Polis — the cultural and political heart of Metro. Each faction has a hero at its disposal. Heroes can travel the underground, gain quests and equipment that increases their abilities, fight opponents' heroes, attack stations, and so on. The army of a faction can also attack stations, and usually with better chances to win, but it can target only adjacent stations. Stations under factions' control produce resources — pigs, ammo and mushrooms — that are used to capture new stations, strenghten the army, buy equipment and obtain quests. The production of resources and other game events are determined by a special sequence. This sequence tells what will happen each round: production of certain recources, a vote for a new law, or a sudden attack from the dark that must be repelled.

Players can attack stations with their armies or their heroes. Both have strength that may be increased by hiring new troops or buying useful equipment. When attacking a neutral station, the army/hero fights a random threat from the special deck and has to beat its strength. When attacking an opponent, the attacker confronts his army or hero. In battles between players a special set of combat cards is used; these cards give various bonuses to strength depending on the card chosen by the opponent, so the goal is to deduce which combat card will be used by the other side.

Game designed to let children test their powers of the German language.

The cards are dealt out evenly (any number can play). In a turn, a player must ask another player to answer correctly the top card in one of three categories; Words that end in g or ch? Words that end in g or k? Words that end in s or z?

If a player answers with the correct spelling ending, he puts the card to his right. If he gets it wrong, it goes to his left. If a player runs out of cards, he must pick up all the cards to his left and play on. The game ends when one player has all his cards to the right and none in his hand.

Down and Around is a game that teaches "The FUN-da-Mentals of Fractions".

From Publisher Website:
Players use our original Fraction Ladder to easily find the Greatest Common Factor (GCF) and Least Common Multiple (LCM) of 2 numbers rolled on the 6- and 12-sided dice. Then players use their answers to be the first to fill-in 9 of their 12 spaces. For a more challenging level players compete to get 3 in a row on either side of the board using both offensive and defensive strategy.

This game comes in a wooden board version and a Masonite board version, for use with crayons or water-based overhead markers.

Wood Version Includes:
- 12" x 12" x 3/4" Birch Game Board
- 80 Glass Marbles (4 colors).
- 4 Marble Trays
- Dice
- Directions
- Game Box

Masonite Version Includes:
- 11" x 11" x 1/8" Masonite board
- Dice
- Directions

Pirates 'n Plunder is a game of "Adding/Subtracting Fractions for Fun!"

From Publisher Site:
Using our original Fraction Ladder, players quickly solve fraction problems with addition and subtraction. Then using these answers, they try to build runs of their marbles for bonus points or to block their opponents' runs. If they plunder (surround) an opponent's treasure chest or include a treasure chest in a run, they score extra points. A fun way to practice adding and subtracting fractions with lots of strategy!

There is a wood board version, and a Masonite board version that be used with crayons or water-based overhead markers.

Wooden Version Includes:
- 12" x 12" x 3/4" Birch Game Board
- 80 Glass Marbles (4 colors).
- 4 Marble Trays
- Dice
- Directions
- Game Box

Masonite Version Includes:
- 11" x 11" x 1/8" Masonite Board
- Dice
- Directions

The theme is based on the darkride "Carnaval Festival" in "De Efteling", a theme park in The Netherlands. The ride is similar to the "It's a small world" ride of Disney fame, but with more red noses.

In the ride you visit the Netherlands, Belgium, the Rivièra, Paris, Great Brittain, Germany, Switzerland, Italy, Japan, China, Alaska, Africa, Mexico and Hawaii. In this game you visit Volendam, Paris, Alaska, Germany, Italy and Africa.

The puppets from Carnaval Festival are hiding out in these six places. For each place there is a cardboardbox that's hiding at least four puppets. The game is a memory game for players of all ages.

The player who collects their pairs of puppets first wins the game.

The players have to "ride" around the board one step at a time, searching for matching pairs of puppets, and bringing them back to START before searching for a new pair. During the game the players have to take surprise cards that will help them further or set them back.

The quickest player with the best memory and the most luck will win the game.

Humorous quiz game about Bavaria.
Goa of the game is to reach Munich first. You can advance through luck of the dice, correct answers, real wealth, misleading other players and ignorance of the other players.
Players roll the dice and if arrow is rolled he moves up the ladder. If "K", "S" or "W" is rolled player takes a creative, estimate or knowledge card from the deck and asks a question.  There is a short game and a team option.

There are groups of words On the 48 cards from which players can make sentences. Depending on the difficulty there is one, two or three points to use. Player with the most points at the end of the game is the winner.

The donkey carries fruits in a basket towards the market, but a bridge is causing problems. The players have their fruit color, depending on the number of players and different numbers of cards, on the remainder pile. With the card, a player can put a fruit in the basket, repair a broken bridge's step or remove the fruit from another player's basket. With the wild card You have  free choice among actions. If the donkey cross the bridge, the player with the most fruits in his basket is the winner.

This game was created by Jennifer Diane Reitz to make part of her fictional universe of Pastel Defender Heliotrope.

It is based on the ancient game of latrunculi or latrunculorum, where players try to eliminate all the opponent's pieces using a "flanking movement" (i.e. pieces surrounding the captured piece in opposite sides). There's little information about movement of pieces, being suggested different ways.

Latrotabuli is a variant played in 12 x 6 retangular board and players have 12 latros and 1 centurion (acts as king). Latros can move any number of spaces in one of the cardinal directions whilst the Centurion can only move one space.

One particular feature of the game is the possibility of creating several formations to best deployment of pieces: the Testudo and the Phalanx. The testudo is a 4-piece square formation and phalanx is a 4-piece linear formation, in which pieces move as one.

The method of capture depends of the capturing formation (or lack of) and of the captured piece/pieces, and can be by approach, by flanking or by moving and replacing.

There's 3 victory conditions: 

     capture all opponent latros (pieces)
     capture the opponent centurion or,
     when a player in the beginning of his turn can't move his centurion, he loses.

Toads&Dragonflies is a tile laying game that is a directly descendant to Hippos & Crocodiles  of nestorgames . Its development was sparked by the contest Nestorgames is constantly holding on BGG for new games. And each abstract deserves a hexed version...:)
You place your animals on the board, whoever can't place his tile looses.

Included in this game are 3 board sizes. The river, the lake and the stream.The later needs 4 tiles, called "boulders" to be placed before choosing your animal.

"The 7 Dwarfs" in english.
The dwarves are numbered and must be combined to form families, which may be the sum not higher than 7. Players score points for entire families. The player with the most points after the deck is exhausted is the winner.

Zombie Mosh puts you in the role of a human survivor or the walking undead in a table top environment, using your scenery and miniatures. It takes place during modern times.

Game-play consists of the sides (survivors and zombies) taking turns with move, shoot and melee phases. The game uses 6 sided dice for all outcomes. There are rules for over 30 different weapons to kill the zombies with and rules for vehicle movement and running down zombies with. There are also several scenarios to use which include maps and modifying suggestions to make each scenario more replayable. Each scenario has different goals and set ups. With these rules it would be easy to play out any scene from any of your favorite zombie movies. There are also all of the markers and templates needed to play included.

Everything is in full color. It is available in pdf format at this time and has 56 pages. Was originally written in 2007, 2.0 was released in 2008 and 2.5 was released in 2011. There is a rumor of a 3.0  release.

Have you ever watched a bad movie and said to yourself, "I could write better than that!" Well, here's your chance!

In Jump the Shark you and your friends are trapped screenwriters who are forced to write bad movies. Even in your poor circumstances, though, you make a gambling game of your situation, so you get the dual fun of making up a great/horrible story and rolling dice. Risk a token for each addition to the scene. Only the last writer and the caller have a shot at the pot. Win the most tokens, and you win the game!

Starzone is a print-and-play game for 2 players set in outer space. Each player battles with a fleet of spacecraft by flicking coins into the Starzone target. The Starzone target is made up of different zones, and asteroids which litter space.  Which zone you hit determines which action you take: you can repair your spacecraft, activate your shields, add or destroy asteroids on the target, or damage your opponent's spacecraft. A special Zone Shift zone on the target allows you to change which actions can be activated by hitting each zone, adding a tactical element to the game. Your spacecraft has different sectors, and the health of each sector is given by hit points. When one sector is destroyed then your spacecraft is destroyed. The first player to destroy three of their enemy's fleet wins the game.

Starzone is a fun and furious game of dexterity and strategy. Outwit your opponent using asteroids and zone-shifts. Find your enemy's weak spot and flick it into outer space!

Party game. Twelve pictures of composite animals are placed around the room. During the party, guests look at the pictures and write down the animals that make up each image. The one who gets the most right answers, wins.

All participants answer the same yes/no question about personal opinions or things done in the past at the same time by inserting a note in to the answer box. Then everyone makes a secret quess about the total number of "Yes"-answers. Those who get the correct answer get one point. The game ends when someone has 10 points.

Questions are designed for adults and might concer even outlaw things.

From the rulebook Designer's note:

"The original version of SC3600 was developed and published by Mariner Games back in 1997. The original launch was accompanied by a small range of miniatures developed by Brigade Models. However the original designers, Patrick Doyle, Mike Tastsides and Doug Glover were serving members of the US armed forces and as such had more pressing demands on their time than playing games, so development of the rules understandably stalled.
[...] We've avoided unnecessary changes to the core rules, being content to tinker around the edges with minor changes to the design system and the inclusion of a hex-less movement system. Our main goal has been to streamline the rules a little without drastically altering the flavour. Probably the one major change has been to do away with the 12-point movement system that allowed movement along hex edges - we abandoned this in our own games very early on. We've also removed the distinction between the Basic and Advanced versions of the game in favour of a single unified set of rules."

The game uses miniatures of starfighters, it is played on a hex map but a set of rules to use hexless maps is also included. The main dice roll used is the 2d6 roll, this is modified by another kinf of dice (ranging from a d4 to a d12) based on the pilot skill. These dice rolls are used to resolve fights and control rolls when your fighter is going spinning around due to damages or wrong manouvers. The damage system is very interesting, being it not the "classic" set of boxes that have to be crossed out but a system that takes in account a series of debilitating damages that during the game, imposing each a number of malus and penalties, can render your fighter inoperative or totally destroyed. Statistics for the official fighter models are in the end of the book.

These are introductory free rules, Brigade Models is going to publish in a near future more complete rules (this time you are going to buy them) that will also include campaign games rules, pilots' skill progression and others more convoluted situations not presented here.
